trial_identification.studytitle: Identifying the differences in the blood chemistry, electrical and structural properties of the heart between participants with and without prior strokes.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Identifying differences in blood biochemistry, cardiac electrophysiological and structural properties between stroke patients and an age matched control group without stroke

interventions.interventions: Exposures of interest are blood biochemistry and the cardiac electrical and structural changes in patients with stroke and comparing them to an age matched control patient cohort without a history of stroke. All measurements will be single point measurements, with no long term component. Exposures: 1) Blood biochemistry: Peripheral and intra cardiac blood samples 2) Cardiac structure: Transthoracic and Transoesophageal echocardiography 3) Cardiac electrical properties: Assessed using 12 lead ECG, Invasive cardiac electrophysiology study.
interventions.comparator: Control population will be age matched patients without a prior history of stroke.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary Outcome : Difference between stroke and control groups in echocardiographic parameters as a composite of left atrial volumetric function, left atrial size and left atrial strain.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Stroke group to undergo an echocardiogram within 3 months of the index stroke

primaryOutcome.outcome:
Primary Outcome : Difference between stroke and control groups with regards to blood markers of inflammation, thrombogenesis and endothelial function.
Composite of IL-6, hsCRP, Thormbin/Antithrombin complex, D-Dimer, ADMA, Von Willebrand Factor, Pro-ntBNP, hsTroponin,
primaryOutcome.timepoint: The biomarkers will be collected from stroke patients within 3 months of index stroke.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary Outcome : Difference between stroke and control groups in electrical substrate
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Stroke patients will undergo electrophysiologic testing within 6 months of index event. Control group will be assessed during routine indicated electrophysiologic studies.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Compare ectopic burden between stroke and control groups as assessed by total number of premature atrial complexes in 24 hours of Holter monitoring.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Single point measure within 3 months of stroke. Control group will be recruited during routine indicated 24 hour monitoring.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Stroke group: Admission diagnosis of ischaemic stroke or TIA, older than 55 years of age Control group: Age matched patients without prior history of stroke or TIA
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. Unable to provide informed consent 2. Pregnancy 3. Chronic kidney disease; stage 4 or greater 4. Patients with significant ventricular arrhythmias on extended monitoring

trial_design.statisticalmethods: Data will be presented as proportions, means and standard deviations, medians with inter-quartile range. Differences between groups will be assessed by a two-sided Chi-Squared Test or Fishers Exact Test for categorical data as appropriate. A Two-sided students T-Test or a non-parametric Wilcoxon Rank Sum Test will be used to compare continuous data as appropriate. A p-value < 0.05 will be considered to indicate statistical significance.

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a fast irregular heart rate that can cause abnormalities in the structure and electrical function of the heart and can cause strokes through formation of blood clots in the heart which move to the brain. A stroke is when blood flow to the brain is interrupted. Although AF is known to increase the risk of stroke, there is new evidence that suggests that other factors may be independently present that cause formation of blood clots in the heart leading to a stroke.
The primary purpose of this study is to identify changes in structure of the heart, the electrical properties within the heart and in the blood chemistry that might increase a persons risk for having a stroke.
